entry.title: Writing Sample
entry.content:
Abstract

In the digital age, internet becomes a rich source of information and maintains network of human social contact. Existing research linking internet usage and teenagers’ cognition outcome focus on the direct exposure of internet users rather than the impact through guardian. In this paper, we use micro data from CFPS to examines the effects of guardian’s choice of using internet on teenager’s cognition achievement. CFPS surveys have been conducted every twice a year since 2010, and it contains a rich set of variables on personal information, parental background, and cognition outcome which allows us to use panel data analysis to identify the causal effect. We find that guardian’s internet usage has a sizable and significant positive effect on teenager’s cognition achievement measured by test scores. Further explore of mechanism shows that both direct channel like learning resources and indirect channel like parental environment are improved for internet using guardian. Heterogeneous analysis shows that the impact is stronger for guardian in rural areas with low education level. The result suggests that promoting internet for the less educated family in rural region can potentially make up the negative background and decrease inequality transmitted across generation.

Introduction

Cognition refers to the capability of analyzing information, solving problems, and making decisions. It measures the variation of human capital and is strongly related toeducation attainment (Jencks et al., 1972; Zagorsky, 2007; Bourne et al., 2018) and latelabor outcome (Thienpont and Verleye, 2004); Heckman et al., 2005). Better cognitionperformance reduces school dropout rate (Belley and Lochner, 2007; Korenman andWinship, 2000), lowers participation in crime (Frisell et al., 2012; Tittle et al., 2003)and increases wage payment (Thienpont and Verleye, 2004). From macro perspective,national cognition level is highly related to economic performance. Hanushek and Kimko(2000) studied the math and science test scores of 31 countries and found that nationalcognition improvements positively affect annual real GDP growth. China ranks highlyon cognition performance, from the perspective of national IQ index, Chinese ranks thesecond highest among the th

entry.title: Keyi GUO
entry.content:
Contact Information
Department of Economics Phone: (852) 97989184
Esther Lee Building Email: kguo6264@gmail.com
The Chinese University of Hong Kong Website: https://guokeyiecon.com
Shatin, HKSAR Skype: 85297989184

Fields of Interest
Applied Microeconomics: Labour Economics, Development Economics, Economic History,
Environmental Economics

Education
The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Shatin, Hong Kong
Master of Philosophy in Economics, GPA: 3.891/4 Sept. 2019 - Jun. 2021
• Advisor: Naijia Guo
Master of Science in Economics, GPA 3.78/4 Sept. 2018 - Jun. 2019
• Dean’s List Certificate, 2018/2019; Excellent Performance Award, 2018/2019
Shandong University, Jinan, China
Bachelor of Art in Finance, GPA 87.64/100 Sept. 2014 - Jun. 2018
• Relative Coursework: Econometrics, Calculus, Linear Algebra, Python Programming, Labor Economics, Industrial Organization, Statistics
University of Wisconsin Madison, Madison, USA
Exchange Program, GPA: 3.885/4 Sept. 2016 - Dec. 2016

Research Experience
Coauthor with Guangsu Zhou Nov. 2019 - Present
• The Paper use micro data from China Family Panel Studies (CFPS) to examine the effects of
guardian’s internet usage on teenager’s cognitive skills.
• Individual fixed effect model and instrumental variable model were applied to identify the causal
effect.
Student Helper of Ying Bai Sept. 2018 - Nov. 2018
• Collected data on territory capitals worldwide. Collected data on city mayors in China.
Research Assistant of Chicheng Ma Mar. 2018 - Jul. 2018
• Read history document \Chinese Historical Geography Rebuilt by Jiaqing".
• Collected data on Chaste women in Sichuan and Guizhou area.
Research Assistant of Chunkai Wang Jun. 2017 - Jul. 2017
• Wrote an article about impacts of FTA on trade relationship between China and Australia.
• The article was collected by China Council for the Promotion of International Trade

Teaching Assistant
Game Theory (ECON 3160), CUHK; Economy of China (ECON 3310), CUHK
Holding office hours. Grading assignments, midterm exam and final report

Computer Skills
Stata, R; some experience with Matlab, Python
